reviews.title: "Been waiting a long time for a mower like this!"
reviews.text: Finally, an affordable, powerful, battery-powered lawn mower that really substitutes for a homeowner's gas-powered mower. This Kobalt 40-volt mower is the equivalent, in my estimation, of a 5-hp gas mower. Of course, you have to charge it, so it won't do a huge yard on one go, but for smaller yards, this is great, and you can always add an additional, comparatively affordable Kobalt battery to extend its range. Everything about this mower is tough, with an incredibly easy set-up and adjustment, right out of the box. Cutting height setting is a breeze. The wheels are sturdy and relatively large, and you can mulch or bag, depending upon your desires. The bag is high-quality and easy to handle. The mower build is sturdy and actually the mower is pretty heavy, but can still be wall-mounted. The best part is no gas with ethanol to ruin your engine. No oil to change and dispose of. No noise to deafen you and no smoke to choke you. No spark plugs to clean and gap. These were all tolerable back in the day when corded electric mowers were like a shock therapy experiment and battery-powered mowers were like toys. Things are different now. This thing really works. And it comes with battery, charger, bag, the whole works in one kit. There are other Kobalt tools that use the same charger and batteries, too, and that is a big plus! Maybe Kobalt will make a canister-vacuum in this 40-volt series at some point. That would be a great idea! By the way, I let my friend who is a landscaper try this out, and he was very impressed.
reviews.author: ARM3

reviews.title: "Sadly Disappointed"
reviews.text: For several years, I've had my eye on these mowers and figured it best to wait several years for the technology to further improve and price to go down. Lowes was running one of those Spring Black Friday sales and the price was quite attractive. Combined with additional discounts, I decided to go for it. The lawn wasn't ready for its first mow until a few weeks afterwards but I was really looking forward to using this new machine.  Setup out the box is simple as it gets and charging the battery only took 2 hours to full charge.  Ergonomics are a definite strong point on this mower - the angle you can set the handle, combined with the curve of the handle and its padding make it extremely comfortable.  Folding the handle back onto itself so as to enable upright storage was a really nice feature.  The way that's designed makes moving the mower around real simple and is an excellent space saver in my otherwise rather crowded shed. As a bonus, the manufacturer 5 year warranty on the mower and 3 year on both charger and battery was very attractive.  With a fully charged battery, I dropped it into the slot where it clicked in nice and secure. Setting the wheel height with just one lever was an absolute delight! While the mower deck is all steel, it's nice and light enough to make it very maneuverable.  The unit's overall simplicity was wonderful and I really liked the color and appearance - so I was pretty excited to use it.Start up is a breeze - another strong positive. When it started, it did kind of mess with my senses as when you're used to a traditional gas powered mower, you expect a certain sound and feel. This thing is super quiet - quieter than a household vacuum cleaner - more positive points there. It does take a few seconds for it to come up to operating speed - which is different when you're used to instant power.  Shut down is also kind of different as the unit sort of winds down to a stop. As for the mowing performance, it's unfortunately here where it started to fall flat and continued to do so.  The lawn was getting its first cut of the season so some grass was not yet tall enough while others were about 4"-5" tall. The mower was set to cut at a 3" height. Making my first passes, I immediately noticed the mower would not lift up heavier weighted leaves and mulch them like a traditional, gas powered push mower. That was surprising but I thought this being a bit different type of equipment so I gave it a little bit of a pass on that.  As I continued to mow into taller grass, which was slightly damp, the unit's motor would occasionally cycle to high revs to compensate for the additional power required and then power down when there wasn't so much of a need.  Continuing along, the taller grass wasn't mulching up as nicely as the traditional mower; lines of clumped grass dotted the yard.  And after a little while, the mower would come to a stop because the grass exiting the side discharge chute became clogged.  I'd have to remove the grass before I could continue. This happened several times.  So one weak point is a small side discharge opening, combined with a lack of engine torque, causes tall, damp grass to clog the unit and force it to stop.  By now, my lawn was going to give me more work to make it look good once I finished mowing.As I was 2/3 of the way through my (less than 5,000 sq ft mowable yard), I was thinking I'd give this mower one more try in a few weeks to see how it performs on a regular basis  However, no sooner did the thought occur when the unit just stopped working.  The reason was the battery completed depleted without warning.  (The battery was fully charged just before it was used.)  Unfortunately, that was the last straw.  I ended up taking out my trusty old gas-powered mower, finished the yard and made passes over the earlier grass clumps where everything looked as to what I've always expected from a mower.I really had such high hopes for this machine and it came extremely close to meeting my expectations.  However, the performance was unacceptable; I need a mower that will make my life and work easier - not give more to do.  Thankfully I was still within the 30 day returns window and was able to do so for a full refund.
reviews.author: Joe

reviews.title: "Loving the Honeymoon"
reviews.text: To be honest, I just got this lawn mower and have only used it once so I am still in the honeymoon phase - but I LOVE IT!To start off after opening the box it probably took all of 5 minutes to set up, during which time I realized the wheel height adjustment for all 4 wheels is easily done with one super simple lever so I was already a happy camper.  After leaving battery on charger for maybe 15 minutes I had a couple bars and didn't want to wait to give Koba a try (that's her name, cuz well she's a girl, duh).  So I slapped the battery in, set the height, pushed a button and we we're off and running.  Immediately I noticed how easy it was to push with it's light weight and it was doing a great job giving a nice even cut to the grass (I did not get the self-propelled, and I don't know why anyone would unless maybe you have hills to deal with).  Next bonus that I wasn't really expecting was that it senses when you are going through some deeper grass and it speeds it's self up to get the job done - we have "smart" everything else, why not a smart mower.Quickly the rest of the story.  I have had a long time hate/hate relationship with lawn mowers.  Honestly I had pretty much decided they are just a disposable item and if I get 3 years out of them that was probably about all I could hope for.  Recently we purchased the house next to our house, so I now have 2 yards to mow, and my 3 year old (sir chugs alot) was about ready for the trash heap, so I treated myself to a riding mower (yeah me).  This still left me with a couple of relatively small backyards that I could partially get with riding mower (not yet named, I'm excepting suggestions), but I was still going to need at least some small mower to get portions of the yard, or better something just to do it all.  I realize the honeymoon might not last forever, and eventually Koba won't be quite as pretty, and might not perform quite as well as she once did, but I am hopeful and look forward to a long and happy relationship.  Seriously though, I would recommend this for anyone in the market for a new mower that has a yard you can mow in 30 - 40 minutes, or pick up a back up battery (the 40V 2.5ah is $76 at lowes) to help get the job done.  It's light weight and ease to use make it ideal for someone that is maybe not a 225lb guy like I am - but great for everyone.
reviews.author: Rick

questions.question: "How long does it take to recharge the battery? And does it come ready to go or do you have to wait the charge time?"
questions.author: Chris

answers.author: Les
answers.text: The killer of all rechargeable batteries is heat, if you start with a full charge and recharge at around half full. It will probably give you good service and longer life. When battery power is high, less current is needed and it will run cooler. But when battery charge starts to get low, the current goes up as the battery power goes down.

answers.author: Dan
answers.text: 2 hours out of the box. Up to 3 hours and 20 minutes after that. Add another hour for the battery to cool down before charging if the battery over heats.

answers.author: sjguy
answers.text: The battery does NOT come with a full charge. After connecting the battery to the charge, the charge light will flash "green". Otherwise, remove and reconnect the battery and watch for the flashing green light. It takes 2 hours to fully charge.

answers.author: Charlie
answers.text: Mine did not e fully charged. Has been on the charger for a half hour so far.

answers.author: HisDudeness
answers.text: Just checked the manual. It says it takes 150 minutes to charge. Mine took longer.

answers.author: HisDudeness
answers.text: It has to be initially charge when removed from the box. It take over 4 hours to initially charge. I was trying to time the charge cycle but got distracted and forgot about it. When I came back several hours later, it was fully charged.

answers.author: Charger68
answers.text: The site will tell you 2.5 hours. Perhaps this is from fully-dead. Mine was 25% charged when I got it and it took over an hour to get it to 100%, perhaps an hour and a half.

answers.text: It does not come charged and I would say it took roughly an hour to charge.

questions.question: "How do you get an extra 40-volt max, 5ah or 4ah Li-ion battery? Can't find one."
questions.author: mlynn

answers.author: Drew
answers.text: Search Item # 710366. It is available special order. Currently sells for $150

answers.author: Phi202
answers.text: Call kobalt customer service. Their number should be on the battery. Don't remember what I paid but was reasonable. Came from Canada and I saved with the exchange rate also.

answers.author: Wev
answers.text: You could build your own, by salvaging 18650 cells from recycled laptop batteries. There are plenty of videos on YouTube on how to do it.

answers.author: lovac1
answers.text: You have to call Kobalt directly to receive a 40V 4amp or 5amp battery. Mine also malfunctioned and they sent me a new one as I was still within the warranty period, but they will also sell you one if the warranty expired. The lady on the phone told me that they are not available in the stores anymore, and the only way to get them is by calling Kobalt. 40v 2amp battery that is available in the stores doesn't really last enough if you have a large yard.

answers.author: Paul
answers.text: You can only get the 2.5 amp battery for the mower at the store for a nice $99 (sarcastic emphasis added). It doesn't last that long. They are foolish to not sell the 5.0 amp battery that came with the mower. If you are paying $300 for a mower, you should at least get enough battery to mow an average lawn so 1 battery barely makes it. Once battery outlives its useful life, the mower will be useless unless you buy multiple 2.5 amp batteries.

questions.question: "Does this (or any other Kobalt Li-ion lawn mower) include a mulching attachment?"
questions.author: John

answers.author: sally
answers.text: In order for the mower to "mulch" you must not use rear bagger and you must not add the side chute. The point of a mulching mower is that it chops what is mown into tiny bits and deposits on the lawn as it mows. This is like fertilizing your lawn, slower but cheaper! I think the rear bagging is what many people think of as mulching. Yes, you can use the grass collected as mulch. Best use is to add to your compost pile as fresh green matter to be broken down. Mulching a border or garden with new grass clippings is okay but don't pile it on too thickly.

answers.author: HisDudeness
answers.text: Yes

answers.author: maconhurler
answers.text: I left the chute closed and it seemed to work as a mulching mower just fine...left very fine small grass clippings.

answers.author: Bill
answers.text: This mower mulches and has a rear mulching plug.

answers.author: Kobalt Team
answers.text: Hello John Yes, this unit has a 3-in-1 feature it offers mulching, rear bagging, or side discharge capabilities. If you still have questions please contact our Kobalt customer service department at 1-866-456-8934.

answers.author: dhpw
answers.text: Yes you can mulch with this mower.

questions.question: "Largest lawn recommended for this system. We have a 0.4 acre lot and aside from the house and garage it's all grass. Will this mower work for us?"
questions.author: Randy

answers.author: John
answers.text: My yard is about 4,500 sqft. The battery lasted half way through it. Grass is Bermuda, about 2-1/2 to 3 inches tall and I set mower on #2 (assuming it means 2 inch cut). The machine cut the grass very nice and smooth, I love it. I also love the concept of going GREEN. Recharging the battery took over a few hours. I don't want to spend all day cutting my grass, nor do I want to spend an extra $150 on an extra 5Ah battery. Unless I can figure a way to mow it all with one charge, I will be returning this for a corded mower or gas. I do agree that we should consider the time of cutting the grass (or hours of charge) more than how much area is cut. Continuous cutting, mine lasted about 1-1/2 hours before needing a charge.

answers.author: Charger68
answers.text: Sounds pretty similar to us. Yes, it should work, as long as you walk quickly, your grass isn't extremely thick, and you keep it regularly mowed/ don't cut it too short (it speeds up and has to work harder in thicker and taller grass, thereby killing the battery life per charge).

answers.author: maconhurler
answers.text: Possibly. If you were trying to mow with the chute closed, you'd have to move slower, so probably not with one charge. Otherwise, maybe the battery would last long enough, but I personally wouldn't trust it to...maybe with a 1/4 to 1/3 acre or so.

answers.author: Bill
answers.text: There are about 43.5K sq. feet in an acre, a little over 17K sq feet. in your lot. I was able to mow about 6000sq. feet before the battery ran out. So, My guess is you would have to recharge twice to finish your lot. I did have to mow in and around hedges, etc., so if I had a straight shot at it, I'm guessing I could have covered 8000 sq. ft.

answers.author: Kobalt Team
answers.text: Hello Randy, The run time for this mower is up to 60 minutes depending on the condition of your lawn with a fully charged 5ah battery. The distance is not a limitation but you will have to recharge the battery as it will require additional run time or you can purchase additional batteries.

answers.author: RLemke
answers.text: I have a quarter acre lot probably 60% grass and I can cut it twice on a full charge and still have one bar left. I would say this lawn mower will work for your size lot.
